title: 107_hr797
content: The "Cuban Humanitarian Trade Act of 2001" allows for the export of agricultural commodities, medicines, medical supplies, instruments, and equipment to Cuba without embargo restrictions. The "Cuban Humanitarian Trade Act of 2001" lifts existing restrictions on trade with Cuba, allowing for the export of agricultural commodities, medicines, medical supplies, instruments, and equipment without embargo limitations. The "Cuban Humanitarian Trade Act of 2001" prohibits the President from restricting the exportation of certain goods to Cuba, except in specific circumstances related to national security threats. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 does not apply to exports of certain goods to Cuba, including agricultural commodities and medical supplies. Amendments are made to specify this exclusion. Amendments are made to the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 by removing subsection (b) and making changes to subsection (a) and (b) regarding exports to Cuba. Amendments are made to the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 regarding sanctions on vessels entering US ports, with exceptions for those transporting specific goods to Cuba. Amendments to the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 include changing the subsection caption from "Donations" to "Exports" and replacing "donations of food to nongovernmental organizations or individuals in Cuba" with "exports of agricultural commodities to Cuba." Additionally, exports of medicines and medical supplies to Cuba are not restricted, except as permitted under the Export Administration Act of 1979. The President must submit a report to Congress before imposing restrictions on exports under the Export Administration Act of 1979. Restrictions are not allowed if there is a likelihood of the item being used for torture, reexported, or used in biotechnological production. The President must submit a report to Congress before imposing restrictions on exports under the Export Administration Act of 1979. Section 1704 of the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 is amended to include definitions for 'agricultural commodity' and 'medicine' as per the Cuban Humanitarian Trade Act of 2001. SEC. 6. Application of denial of foreign tax credit with respect to Cuba: Amends section 901(j)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code to exempt Cuba from certain foreign tax credit denials for income, war profits, or excess profits taxes related to activities permitted under the Cuban Humanitarian Trade Act of 2001. SEC. 7 prohibits limiting annual remittances to Cuba by individuals under U.S. jurisdiction, with exceptions for money laundering offenses. SEC. 8 states that other restrictions do not apply. SEC. 8 states that other restrictions do not apply. SEC. 9 requires a report to Congress. SEC. 9 requires the President to report to Congress on sales of goods to Cuba, including agricultural commodities and medical supplies, to assess if they were used for human rights abuses or reexported. SEC. 10 defines "agricultural commodity" as per the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 and includes fertilizer, while "medicine" is defined as per the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act.
